CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

The "Material Name" entities in the paragraph are:

1. POBDTPD
2. PEBDTPD
3. BDT
4. DTPD
5. PC 60 BM
6. PC 70 BM
7. PEDOT
8. PSS
9. TiO2
10. Al

These are the names of the materials used in the synthesis and fabrication of the low band gap polymers and solar cell devices.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Sure, here are the entities that clearly refer to Material Name in the given paragraph:

1. POBDTPD
2. PEBDTPD
3. BDT
4. DTPD
5. PC 60 BM
6. PC 70 BM

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Sure, here's a Markdown table with the valid entities in the "Material Name" column:

| Material Name |
| --- |
| POBDTPD |
| PEBDTPD |
| BDT |
| DTPD |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the property names of materials in the paragraph:

1. POBDTPD - polymer
2. PEBDTPD - polymer
3. BDT - dialkoxybenzodithiophene (donor)
4. DTPD - N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (acceptor)
5. PC 70 BM - [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester (fullerene derivative)
6. ITO - indium tin oxide (electrode material)
7. PEDOT:PSS - poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrene sulfonate) (electrode material)
8. TiO2 - titanium dioxide (electrode material)
9. Al - aluminum (electrode material)

Note that some of the materials mentioned in the paragraph, such as solvents and other materials used in the fabrication process, are not listed here as they are not relevant to the property names of the materials.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

Sure, here's the updated list of entities that refer to Property Name of Material:

2. PEBDTPD
3. BDT
4. DTPD
5. PC 70 BM

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

1. First, let's identify the material properties mentioned in the paragraph:

* Band gap
* HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) level
* LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) level
* Power conversion efficiency (PCE)
* Voc (open-circuit voltage)
* Jsc (short-circuit current density)
* FF (fill factor)
* Carrier mobility
* Nanoscale phase separation
* Surface smoothness
2. Next, let's look at the values of these material properties mentioned in the paragraph:

* Band gap: ∼ 900 nm (for the polymers)
* HOMO level: -5.3 eV (for the DTPD acceptor moiety)
* LUMO level: -4.0 eV (for the DTPD acceptor moiety)
* PCE: 4.7% (for the POBDTPD device) and 5.3% (for the PEBDTPD device)
* Voc: 0.70 V (for the POBDTPD device) and 0.72 V (for the PEBDTPD device)
* Jsc: 10.6 mA/cm^2 (for the POBDTPD device) and 13.5 mA/cm^2 (for the PEBDTPD device)
* FF: 0.64 (for the POBDTPD device) and 0.54 (for the PEBDTPD device)
* Carrier mobility: not explicitly mentioned, but the text suggests that the higher carrier mobility in the PEBDTPD device contributed to its higher Jsc
* Nanoscale phase separation: not explicitly mentioned, but the text suggests that the better nanoscale phase separation in the PEBDTPD device contributed to its higher Jsc
* Surface smoothness: not explicitly mentioned, but the text suggests that the smoother surface of the PEBDTPD device contributed to its higher Jsc
3. Finally, let's convert the values to the appropriate units:

* Band gap: 900 nm (nanometers)
* HOMO level: -5.3 eV (electronvolts)
* LUMO level: -4.0 eV (electronvolts)
* PCE: 4.7% (percent) and 5.3% (percent)
* Voc: 0.70 V (volts) and 0.72 V (volts)
* Jsc: 10.6 mA/cm^2 (milliamps per square centimeter) and 13.5 mA/cm^2 (milliamps per square centimeter)
* FF: 0.64 (dimensionless) and 0.54 (dimensionless)
* Carrier mobility: not explicitly mentioned (units would depend on the specific measurement)
* Nanoscale phase separation: not explicitly mentioned (units would depend on the specific measurement)
* Surface smoothness: not explicitly mentioned (units would depend on the specific measurement)

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

Sure, here's the updated list of entities that refer to the Value of Material Property:

1. Band gap
2. HOMO level
3. LUMO level
4. Power conversion efficiency (PCE)
5. Voc (open-circuit voltage)
6. Jsc (short-circuit current density)
7. FF (fill factor)

These are the entities that directly relate to the value of material properties in the context of solar cells. The other entities mentioned in the previous list, such as nanoscale phase separation and surface smoothness, are important for the performance of solar cells but do not directly refer to the value of material properties.
